info.game_comments: April Fools' Day show with Pat Sajak as host.

(1, 1).clue: This "A" word means to relinquish power or give up the throne

(2, 1).clue: In 1991, after 8 years as the AKC's top dog, the cocker spaniel lost the No. 1 ranking to this dog called a lab

(3, 1).clue: Upton Sinclair wrote "The Jungle" & he wrote "The Jungle Book"

(4, 1).clue: Bruce Willis can toast her with a demitasse when they celebrate their tenth anniversary November 21, 1997

(5, 1).clue: Maid of Orleans with a monument at the end of the Champs Elysees
(5, 1).correct response: the Joan of Arc de Triomphe

(6, 1).clue: This man's Chicago-based Rainbow/PUSH action network is a merger of 2 earlier political groups

(1, 2).clue: We're looking for an "I"; it's an animal without any backbone

(2, 2).clue: Chillicothe was this state's capital twice, losing out to Zanesville once & finally to Columbus

(3, 2).clue: Much of "Fools Die", a novel by this "Godfather" author, centers on gambling & Las Vegas

(4, 2).clue: Queen Victoria exulted over her honeymoon night with him, "I never, never spent such an evening!!!"

(5, 2).clue: Jerry Garcia's ancient Biblical texts from Qumran

(6, 2).clue: On TV he played Steve McGarrett, head of Five-O, a special Hawaiian police unit

(1, 3).clue: This "O" is the medical branch that deals with the anatomy & treatment of the eye

(2, 3).clue: Only twice between 1949 & 1964 did this team fail to win the American League pennant

(3, 3).clue: Arthur C. Clarke wrote this 1968 sci-fi novel in collaboration with director Stanley Kubrick

(4, 3).clue: Her cousin Maria Shriver was her matron of honor when she married Edwin Schlossberg in 1986

(6, 3).clue: He played for the Kansas City Monarchs before he joined the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1947

(1, 4).clue: It's what the Greeks call the letter "E"

(2, 4).clue: After a 3-year ride at the top in U.S. sales, this Honda model lost its No. 1 position to the Taurus in 1992

(3, 4).clue: She dazzled readers with "Dazzle" & "I'll Take Manhattan"

(4, 4).clue: Daniel Day-Lewis married this playwright's daughter Rebecca after starring in the film version of "The Crucible"

(6, 4).clue: This actress who now plays Lisa Landry on "Sister, Sister" won an Emmy for "227"

(1, 5).clue: "U" may not be aware that this Florentine palace was originally built for Cosimo I de Medici

(2, 5).clue: This orator was the Democrats' presidential nominee twice, lost a turn & was nominated again in 1908

(3, 5).clue: Lt. Joe Leaphorn & Navajo policeman Jim Chee return in this author's 1996 mystery "The Fallen Man"

(4, 5).clue: This "Fantasia" conductor was a vigorous 63 when he married 21-year-old Gloria Vanderbilt in 1945

(6, 5).clue: Formerly a special advisor to LBJ, he's presided over the MPAA since 1966

(1, 1).clue: P.T. Barnum exhibited a monkey sewn to a fish as one of these female sea creatures from "Feejee"

(2, 1).clue: On April 8, 1974 this Brave hit his 715th home run

(3, 1).clue: Term for material, like dry wood or newspaper, used to start a fire

(4, 1).clue: The humans in this play inspire Puck to say, "Lord, what fools these mortals be!"

(5, 1).clue: Alchemists once searched for the philosopher's stone, said to transmute base metals into this substance

(6, 1).clue: This happens "Where angels fear to tread" & "where wisemen never go"

(1, 2).clue: A 1985 April Fools' issue of this magazine told of Sidd Finch, the pitcher with the 168 mph fastball

(2, 2).clue: It was lullaby & goodnight for this composer who died in Vienna April 3, 1897

(3, 2).clue: A carboniferous solid fuel for blast furnaces, or a carbonated liquid fuel for people

(4, 2).clue: Though this historical play contains a clown, it's the heroine who makes an asp of herself

(5, 2).clue: Former astronaut James Irwin led 5 expeditions to this mount to recover Noah's Ark

(6, 2).clue: Sergio Mendes & Brasil '66 had a hit with this Beatles tune from the "Magical Mystery Tour" album

(1, 3).clue: in 1678 England panicked at false rumors of a takeover plot by this order founded by Loyola

(2, 3).clue: Filipino chieftain Lapu-Lapu & his forces killed this Portuguese explorer April 27, 1521

(3, 3).clue: This partly-decayed plant matter is a common fuel in areas without much coal

(4, 3).clue: Trinculo is a jester in this "stormy" drama

(5, 3).clue: Although Plato pointed toward Gibraltar, many modern scientists place this mythical island near Crete

(6, 3).clue: This question precedes "Who never fell in love, it seems that I'm the only one that I have been thinking of"

(1, 4).clue: David Hampton's exploits posing as this actor's son inspired the play & film "Six Degrees of Separation"

(3, 4).clue: Also called lamp oil, this petroleum product was once the chief source of artificial lighting

(4, 4).clue: Dogberry & Verges are 2 foolish officers in this comedy whose title may mean "nada" to you

(5, 4).clue: John Franklin was lost at sea searching for this American waterway

(6, 4).clue: In 1981 Diana Ross cracked the Top Ten with a remake of this 1956 Frankie Lymon & The Teenagers hit:"Why do birds sing so gay /And lovers await the break of the day..."

(2, 5).clue: On April 12, 1961 Yuri Gagarin blasted off in a capsule called this, Russian for "east"
